title: My new spouse purchased a home and I'm filing Chpt 7. Is his home a joint asset even though I'm not on title?
question: I've been married for 8 months and am contemplating filing Chapter 7. We are still residents of CA, but, have been in OH for work. My partner purchased a home in OH. I have $265k debt (student loan and unsecured bad debt) from before we were married. I don't want him to suffer adverse actions or have his property title involved. How should I go about doing this? (I'm waiting for an atty consult).
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Divorce and student loans,Community property in divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Prenups and divorce,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Prenuptial agreement
answers:
The real estate will be considered community property (jointly owned by both spouses) even if the title is in his name. If there is equity you could claim a $100,000 exemption in the property. Keep in mind that the income of both spouses will "count" in a chapter 7 case; you'd have to report your husband's income. The combined income would be used to determine if you are qualified under the Means Test.

Secondly, you may want to do some research about how student loans are handled in bankruptcy. In the typical chapter 7 case, student loan debt is listed in the schedules but IS NOT discharged. The debtor can attempt to discharge the debt by filing an "adversary complaint" at the same time as petition is filed. The adversary action is litigated against the student loan creditors. The debtor would seek to prove that repayment of the student loans would constitute an "undue hardship." Most people are discouraged from seeking a discharge of student loans because of the effort involved and the likelihood that the court will find in favor of creditors and reject the attempt to discharge the student loan debt.

Finally: student loans are typically the responsibility of the spouse that obtained the loan, but this gets complicated when the couple is married for years, the education of the borrower is valuable because it enlarges the couple's income and community property. In a divorce situation, he would want you to agree that he is not responsible for any portion of your student loan debt. You may agree with this in principle, but down the road, this may change. To protect your spouse from potential liability for your student loan debt, discuss your situation with a family law attorney that handles pre-nuptial and post-nuptial agreements.
I agree with attorney Steingraber. There are a lot of moving parts to you question and I would urge you to meet with a bankruptcy attorney to explore all your options.

More information is needed to give you useful advice: 1. What is the breakdown between the student loan debt and the unsecured "bad debt"? How is title to the OH property vested? (is your name on the deed?) Where are you planning to file? CA or OH? When are you planning to file? These are some of the questions you will have to answer when you have your consultation with the BK lawyer.
